reviewText:
I can't believe I didn't write a review for this game earlier!

LLtQ is a visual novel about an underage girl whose mother dies and will soon become the queen when she comes of legal age. The problem with this however is that their are many people who stand to gain from her demise and taking over her kingdom so she not only needs to blossom into a woman extremely quickly, she must also remain alive while doing so whch is harder than it sounds with so, so many ways to die just waiting for you.

The game is a joy to play in large parts due to its simple but great writing. Your character is believable because you dictate how she should behave and the choices have weight to them. If the game just stuck to this formula it would still be a fun game but supernatural elements come into play and while you can choose to be a magical princess you have to keep in mind that time spent learning your magical powers is time taken away from ruling your kingdom and trying to juggle everything perfectly is impossible (the game is purposely designed that way) so you are usually choosing between the lesser evil but do you even care? I mean with everyone out to kill you, aren't you just doing what needs to be done to survive?

Your villagers may not see it that way, so be careful! Nor may the very people you thought you could trust and is that dad with another woman so quickly after mom died?!

The game can become quite dark and even depressing at times but that is just part of the charm because it is your actions that are causing the other people to react and while it is tempting to appease others you also have to survive as well and lets not forget that your mother just died too, so maybe you don't want to deal with all these pressures right now.

If I make the game sound difficult it really isn't. You will die but since it is a novel and not an actual living game (IE Civ5) you can eventually die your way to success after you know what to expect. This doesn't mean however that the game loses replay value as it has multiple endings that reflect the actions you took so if you are a completionist, you will find many hours of replay value to be had here.

I heartily recommend this game!

reviewText:
I see this compared to Princess Maker all the time. Having never played PM, I'm no expert, but LLtQ is much more story-driven than PM, which is sort of sandboxy. I actually like the narrative aspect, since it allows you to make plans to get around what killed you last time. Of course, by improving one skill you'll have skimped on some other, which may actually prevent you from getting as far as you did last time.

That said, this is still a terribly amusing game. You can mistreat Elodie horribly, like making her visit her mother's grave constantly and reinforcing the futility of all her efforts. After all, she's gonna die, too. Probably. And messily. But first she'll embarrass herself, perhaps by tripping over her dress at the ball. You could have avoided that by teaching her reflexes or composure, but who needs that when you can study naval strategy?

Uh, not that I approve of abusing princesses. That was just an exposition on possibilities. In all, I recommend this to people who understand Losing is Fun.

reviewText:
This game looks like it's pretty and pastel and of absolutely no consequence whatsoever.

Five or six deaths later, you may begin revising that assessment.

This is a strategy game. This is a game about staying alive in a hostile environment. You will die. Repeatedly. To the same things that you died to before.

You could lose a civil war.
You could lose an uncivil war.
You could annoy someone by killing their family and be run through in a duel.
You could be shot by bandits.
You could be blown up by an enemy mage.
You could eat poisoned chocolate.
That's not even half of all the ways that you can die in the short year before you inherit.

And if you're crowned, that most distant possibility? Well, sure, you might have taken the kingdom. The question is, will that kingdom still be worth ruling?

You won't be done with this game until you've achieved your perfect realm and learnt all the secrets hidden from your blissfully unaware heir.

After all... How did your late mother, the queen, pass away, anyway?

reviewText:
Luck-based trial and error and error and error and error, effectively lacking interactivity.

This reminds me of Time Gal, where part of the fun can be seeing all the different ways your female protagonist can die over and over again in cutesy ways. The problem is that victory in Long Live The Queen is completely luck based, and even if you get near the end then restart, powered by the knowledge of what's to come, you'll still not get all the way through.

The idea is that you train your stats, while constantly receiving situations (these aren't randomised, though that can be slightly different paths depending on outcomes) that test these stats. If you trained one or two stats high enough, you pass. It might matter, it might not, it might change something in a few turns' time.

But there's very little give. Even if you die and reload a save from a few turns back, you might train the stat high enough to pass, only to soon die again for not having another stat. So you have load an even earlier save to train both the stats high enough, but then you die earlier because one of the stats you didn't train wasn't high enough. It's a cycle that isn't fun.

The idea had a lot of potential, but it only works if there are several ways to an ending (early deaths don't count as satisfying endings), which would be based on your personal approach to being a leader. Instead, you just get killed off unless you have certain stats up to certain levels by a certain point in time, without being given any clues.

To get to the end, you'll likely need to follow a guide to the letter. But then what's the point of playing?

reviewText: Long Live the Queen is not your typical Visual Novel RPG. Rather, I like to refer to it more as a spoiled-teenage-dress up-monarchy simulator
date:
but in a surprisingly fun and addictive way. Elodie is a 14 year old princess who you must guide over a 40 week in-game period on the road to her coronation ceremony to become Queen once she reaches her 15th birthday. Only problem is...almost everyone else in the other kingdoms wants to see her fail or die before the 40 weeks have passed.

Essentially, each playthrough is inherently unique based on the classes you have Elodie take to progress her skills each week; The classes you assign Elodie and the story's plot progress at a week by week level instead of a day by day format. The amount of progress she makes in each skill every week will depend upon her mood that week and which two skills you decide she should learn at that time (morning and evening class schedule). In order to change her mood from week to week, you must choose certain paths to take in the game, pass or fail in-game events, and/or vary her evening plans each week. Her progress in certain skills and the choices you make each week can mean the difference between life and death for Elodie. One of the beautiful, albeit frustrating, features of the game is that there is no way to make Elodie good at everything. There is a system that almost forces you to actively think through each decision you make, which adds to the complexity of the story and gameplay overall.

There is a plethora of ways to win and multiple endings as well, many of which have Elodie dying before the coronation ceremony, but every ending is based upon the decisions you made throughout the game 'til that endpoint. However, there are many events that are locked-in which you cannot avoid; this is one of the negative aspects of the game in my opinion as it makes the story seem more linear in progression and not as dynamic. Despite all of this, if Elodie manages to survive to the end she will always be crowned Queen... but what kind of Queen you become, what kind of Kingdom you create in the future, and how you get there exactly depends on your stats and decisions. I cannot reiterate this wonderful facet of decision-making in the game enough (if you cannot tell). Also, the game allows you to see your entire runthrough and the choices you made via textlog whenever you reach an endpoint should you want a recap or printoff of it in detail.

In conclusion, I recommend this game only to players who like visual novels, who are persistent, and are not easily discouraged or rage at their failures, because you WILL fall short in this game numerous times I assure you. Some people have used guides in the past even due to its difficulty to give you an idea of what to expect if you buy it. However, I submit that if you are dedicated to the plot, enjoy struggles only to try again to better yourself, and have plenty of time to put into the game, then you will most likely enjoy it. I know there are mixed feelings about the game, and I have displayed some of those feelings within this review. As such, I give Long Live the Queen a Solid 7.5 or 8 out of 10. While it is very difficult, lengthy, and possesses a somewhat linear plot, the game also has a great story, challenging decision-making aspects, and adaptive gameplay mechanics. Plus, it is always fun to dress her up in various new clothes based on her skill sets. So if you do choose to grab this game, I say to get it while it is on steam sale. Good luck, and hopefully you won't die. Regardless, of if you do-- LONG LIVE THE QUEEN!

reviewText: What drives a man of God to wash away the sins of his past, only to blacken his heart with a multitude more? How far can a freedom fighter be pushed before virtue and righteousness are replaced by a lust for vengeance? What does a privileged society do when the foundation of its prosperity is shaken? Long Live The Queen dares to explore these heady themes and many more, giving you glimpses at just how the seemingly smallest of decisions can forever alter our realities, and our hearts. As a young princess, your actions bring turmoil and strife to an ostensibly idyllic landscape. It's immensely fun to stir up trouble, and even more engaging to see how boldly Long Live The Queen portrays a society torn asunder. You'll be haunted by this thematically devastating adventure, and indeed, its phenomenal final minutes, which are bound to be discussed and dissected for some time to come.

reviewText: Despite its appearance, Long Live the Queen is not a Japanese dating sim. Instead, it's a surprisingly compelling RPG. You develop your character's skills over the course of the game and these skills determine the outcome of the game's many events. In turn, these outcomes create branches that affect how you progress through the game's narrative. Possible branches include civil wars, foreign invasions, forest adventures and chocolate-induced fatalities. If you survive until your coronation, the game's many endings explain the long-term consequences of your actions (Fallout style). As a result, there's a ton of replayability if you  want to find every possible permutation of the game's story.\n\nDon't let its look deceive you; Long Live The Queen is a game worth playing for anyone who enjoys story-driven RPGs.

reviewText: I've played much longer than the 4 hours shown, I bought this before it came to Steam and spent so many hours just playing or dying really before I pulled out the old fashioned pencil and paper and began to write down each and everything I tired and different things I learned along the way to get through this game. The end result had over ten sheets of paper with my findings on it... then of course I discovered the online walkthrough but that's another story... however the point is I spent much of my time making strategies and of course dying but it was all in good fun! This game is most certainly a 10/10 and I'd recommend it even to those who are'nt into visual novels it's just that entertaining :)

reviewText:
Long Live The Queen is a raising sim where you train a princess in a variety of social, physical, intellectual and mystical skills. Depending on your choices, her mood affects how quickly she learns in her classes. The gameplay is very similar to games such as The Sims, The Idolmaster and Princess Maker.

Unlike conventional raising sims, there is little time to worry about how to raise a perfect little princess. Angry citizens, rival nobles, neighboring countries, monsters and other dangers lie at every corner. After the first few playthroughs, you soon realize that the game is extremely ruthless and unforgiving - simply staying alive becomes the first priority. In a world where everyone is after your head, can you ensure your princess survives till her coronation?

Overall, I'd describe the game as a cross between Dark Souls and Princess Maker. Highly recommended to those looking for a unique and challenging simulation game. And despite the malice and cruelty it often rewards, there are a few light-hearted and gentle moments as well.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Long Live The Queen is an intuitive interactive story game that paints a portrait of a kingdom falling apart at the seams as their new princess takes control of the kingdom when her mother, the queen, dies. With assassinations, executions, magic, financial problems, a civil war, naval and military battles, and countless other troubles, Long Live The Queen provides a little bit of everything, creating a game that everyone can thoroughly enjoy. This game is fun, addictive even, with a richly deep storyline and unpredictable action around every corner. Long Live The Queen provides countless hours of gameplay, and with each death, a chance to make better choices the next turn around, as you try to protect Elodie until her coronation day.

reviewText: A quirky visual novel game with cutsey anime characters. So it's all flowers and sunshine, right? Wrong. This game is surprisingly brutal in parts and isn't afraid to make your princess die horribly in several places (and give you achievements for it!), as well as letting you dish it out as well (I took someone's head off in a duel, had someone assassinated, and a few executions as well. Fun!). The game is basically entirely made up of reading stuff and making choices on either events or your weekly schooling, which determines your skills that figure into what you can and cannot do. It can actually be difficult to beat, but once you do you probably will have the game figured out and you won't have too much trouble with that afterwards. If it does have replay value, it is to get all the achievements, which are impossible to get in a single playthrough. It will take alot of them...\n\nSo is it worth it? Well it was more interesting than I expected, but it's still less a game and more a choose your own adventure book. If you like that sort of thing, this may be worth looking at. :)

reviewText:
This is a well written visual novel. This game, despite playing for just an hour and a half ... is amazing. I love it.

However, despite this is an anime while it features a pretty girl with pink hair.. and the fact she's a princess- this isn't a game for the faint of heart. It's actually a strategy game where you must choose your actions carefully while advancing in a variety of skills. One wrong move, or one wrong step... you will die, brutally. I don't even mean in a funny way- you'll see your Queen murdered or killed in ways you didn't expect.

It makes your heart race, knowing if you weren't prepared or ready for a certain situation... you can end up screwed over. Luckily you can load from your save, but this game will push you into REALLY thinking things through.

I highly suggest that you check the game out. It's awesome and everything about it proves itself being worthy of playing. Plus, it's a successful Indie game that won the Greenlight vote. So that there already says something about the game.

reviewText: I haven't had this much fun with a visual novel game since Virtue's Last Reward. Long live the Queen provides an addictive story with an incredible number of branching paths. Don't save mid playthrough just to take different forks in the story. Challenge yourself to take on each playthrough letting the consequences fall. Even when you fail, you'll walk away with a rivetting narrative experience.

reviewText:
It's quite a small game with lovely, cute art and dialogue. But even though it is small, it seems you have several ways to reach the end or by meeting your end.
The basic story is that your mother, the queen, died and in 1 year you will be crowned the new queen of the realm. However, you need to survive by making the right choices.

Every turn you pick 2 attributes you want to level, followed by an event. The events are always the same except if a specific skill is high enough to know what you are doing. This makes it in a way less random and after playing it a few times, you will know what is to come most of the times.

However, the more you play, the more you will learn about the people, the land, your allies, your enemies, etc. This can somewhat give you more reason to play and increases the replayability. Otherwise, when you finished the game once, you are pretty much done, which can be fast as turns are done by weeks. So you have 52 turns before the game is over. Beter spend your decisions wisely.

While the game has lovely graphics and dialogue, it certainly is not Princess Maker (A game which I played a lot during my childhood), which I hoped it was the first time I saw this game appearing on steam. Nevertheless, I certainly recommend this game if you like a short, cute, replayable visual novel.

reviewText:
This is one of those kind of games where you either don't expect much or you're not sure what to expect. Do not let the 'anime-kawaii-uguuu'ness scare you off and make you think less of this game.
I was personally pleasantly surprised by this game, a text adventure accompanied by 2d images and an ocean of different choices which each can actually affect later outcomes. This can be learning about production and trade to help fund a business which will aid you later or having a high reflex, knowledge of archery and composure to avoid getting yourself killed. Do you want to focus on internal affairs? Have more knowledge about military stragedy? The list goes on and on and you can complete the game many times in so many different ways that its even worth its full price.
The music does loop a lot but is still enjoyable. I personally wish there was more story than there is as the game feels short, but again the replayablity somewhat makes up for that in the long end.
I'd say give it a whirl, especially if its on sale. 6-7/10 in my eyes.

reviewText:
Quite a nice little game. Not as in-depth as one would like, but the number of possible outomes to events as well as different paths is staggering. However, to expand upon my early statement, things are not random nor do they allow for more flexibility when learning skills, so it is very hard to actually do anything new.

For instance, I may not have enough Lore or Foreign Affairs to know this one thing because I only had a day to study two skills. Perhaps an increase in classes per day could overcome this.

All in all, a fantastic game, and I'm right now starting my military despot run. I will take my people into civil war hereby unknown to the world.

reviewText:
Absolute gem of a game, really can't recommend this enough. It's a sort of visual novel with many branching plots and you must guide Elodie, the soon to be Queen through the following year safely to her coronation. Every week you choose skills to advance and have to deal with various situations in the kingdom (which is where all the story comes in). Your chosen skills then affect how you can deal with things.

Elodie is quite endearing but despite the cutesy artistic style this is anything but. Your death is assured with various assassination attempts, murders, accidents, monsters and so on ready to bring about your untimely demise. You can play in a vast variety of ways giving this huge re-playability. Replaying is a must if you want to see the huge variety of paths this story can take.

The music is quite fittign and really adds tot he mood. When something tragic is going to happen appropriate music plays, something sad starts - sad music start, really adds to the feelings you get from the story.

Gem of a game, really hope there is a sequel of sorts. Totally recommend this, it is a fantastic game, don't let it remain hidden!

reviewText:
This game is Persona meets Tsukihime. If that description means anything to you, you should buy this game. Long Live the Queen has surprisingly good gameplay, especially considering that it's a visual novel. The mechanics give you the feeling that you're plotting and planning (not just navigating a tree), and every bit of knowledge that is beyond your reach will make you paranoid.

The mechanics mesh well with the story to create a a feeling that you're making decisions, and not just clicking options or increasing stats. The writing is also top notch, which allows the game to cover very dark subjects with a light tone.

The central mechanic revolves around skill checks. You have around 42 distinct skills grouped into 14 sets of 3, that you can chose to increase each week by studying. The rate at which you learn a skill is based upon other skills you've learned in that set and category, and is significantly based upon your mood. Elode's mood will help and hinder your rate of learning significantly. You change Elode's mood by doing various activities, which makes the game feel a bit like Persona, but most activities modify multiple moods at once, which gives moods some inertia. So when you're playing you need to think carefully about what mood you want to be in next, and how you'll get there.

The writing for this game is wonderful. The aesthetics of the game and the introduction will tend to make you too naive your first play through, until some offended noble draws a sword and slits a criminal's throat right in front of you. There is no graphic violence, but the violence described is intense, and it will make you paranoid and fearful, even after you're done with the game.

reviewText: A fairly deep and engrossing game of making choices and facing the consequences later on. It has the trappings of a cutsie visual novel, but its actually a very cut-throat strategy game. Its very simply about choosing what skills to level up, which can vary based on your mood, but choosing the right thing at the right time is critical to not ending up with a sword in your chest. Events unfold, and based on what you know you may pass or face different choices.\n\nIts hard not to want to immediately see if you'd made different choices in skills if you could have achieved a different outcome. Saving regularly is  recommended. I managed to reach a number of deaths with my story before I felt it was best to scrap everything and start from the beginning again with what I had learned. I figure it will take a number of playthroughs to reach the various story threads and perhaps find one that leads to a good outcome.

reviewText:
This is a short game if you're quick to grasp what to do to 'win'. There's the thing though, for me this game isn't about making it until the end, it's about being able to discover all the story behind it, get all the achievements and seeing all the endings. I haven't played much and I've already 'won', so if that is all you care about I wouldn't bother with this game as you'll probably either get tired of it or won't really feel it was worth your time.

Now that's out of the way, I absolutely loved how you could change the way the story developed. It's been a lot of fun trying to play in all sorts of crazy and spontaneous manners to see what happens. If you like exploring different options and discovering new things each time you'll definitely like this game. It's true some skills end up being pretty useless and can be substituted by others, but I consider that part of the process of learning how the game develops, making you realize how you should spend your points to achieve different outcomes.

All in all it's a fun game, I recommend it ;)

reviewText:
Pros:
I like the outfits you can dress Elodie in
I really enjoy that when you take a class, there's a snippet of information about the topic
The angel of music ending is really beautiful.

Cons:
The story is very linear
You aren't free to train Elodie as you want, unless you want her to die you have to train her in the skills the game decides she should have.
Skill checks feel really arbitrary
Since your choices don't necessarily change the story, replaying for different outcomes/achievements/whatever gets pretty tedious really quickly

I really wanted to like this game, it's such a neat idea! But it's honestly just not fun for me. It was hard until I ran into all the ways to die, and then it just became tedious as I had to give up on training skills that I liked to train ones that I had no interest in every time I replayed it just so I didn't fail the skill check and die. Getting to the end isn't even fun, because it's not like I can beat it by training an Elodie that I think would make a good queen. It feels unfair that you have all these options but most of them are not actually viable choices. Gameplay feels less like customizing your princess and more like guessing which skills she'll need to stay alive.

reviewText:
First, this game is hard. Or rather, extremely frustrating. There are basically two fun playthroughs : the first one, for the amount of customization and choices you can make in general, and the last one, for getting that one ending you've worked for.

Everything in between is hell. Prepare to save every single week and do a lot of backtracking. There's a final boss of sorts, which serves as the major obstacle in the game and will require a lot of planning and re-planning.

Other than that, it's a pretty sweet game. The gameplay is unique and the plot is fun to go through.

reviewText: I bought the game during a sale and got a loooot more enjoyment out of it than I initially expected. It's great fun to spend the first while playing the full game through, trying to figure out how to reach coronation without falling prey to unfortunate events (they usually result in your death, but there are other fates that are unsatisfying enough to make you want to try again, too!). Once you've gotten to coronation once or twice, the list of deaths-I mean!-endings is an interesting checklist to complete (I only have one left!), and some of the achievements sound pretty interesting and fun to unlock as well. I'm saving heavily now to be able to tweak my skills without having to restart from scratch, but at this point even if I don't manage to get them all I'm pretty happy with my purchase and looking forward to trying out other games from the developer.\n\nEdited to add: Playing other VNs is helping me better understand why this one is so good. What you choose to study every week has a clear, visible impact on what may happen during the following week(s), because you see what skills are being checked. You can play a very different game depending on what skills you choose to focus on (e.g., I had a go at being nice the first time around and after the humiliating ending it led me to, I ended up putting all my points in military and executing everyone given half a chance in the next run-through ;) Which opened up new storylines I'd had no visibility in until then). You can have spies and send them out to do your bidding. There is no romance as a central plot point and choosing to marry someone (or not) is a more tactical decision. The default" plot also makes it obvious that there are other storylines you might be interested in unlocking (e.g. the birthday party
date: Briony) to explore the game/world/deaths even further. Basically playing other games is making me like this one even more :-)"

reviewText:
I had originally only bought this game to try to prove how easy it would be... and boy was I wrong.
This game is absolutely INFURIATING in the specificity of skill levels.
This game is also probably the most addicting game I've ever bought on Steam.
Infuriating and addictive are probably the two best words I can think of to describe this game.

I was able to actually BEAT the game and make it to my coronation within my first six tries (HUZZAH), but as a naturally competitive person, I am compelled to keep working this game until I reach each and every ridiculous achievment in the game.

How do I get blessed by cats? How do I demand sacrifices? WHERE IS THE TENTACLE DEATH?
Until I find these things out, I cannot feasibly stop playing this game.

I reccomend this to... really anyone who likes storyboard games, or enjoys games driven by plot and not action.

reviewText: Don't let the sugary pinkness scare you away from this game: there's more virtual death in this game than you can shake a stick at. Or do you charm the whole world with your social graces?

reviewText:
Long Live The Queen (LLTQ) is a visual novel with the addition of a rather big skill tree, with skills affecting both the choice of decisions as well as the outcome of many situations. Failure (as in having your skill not high enough) often results in the death of the protagonist Elodie, whom the player controls/takes actions for.

The goal of the game is to survive long enough for Elodie to become crowned queen and the game is not short of obstacles planted in your way and killing Elodie off in quite a few ways, including but not solely consisting of being penetrated by arrows, killed by monsters, stabbed, getting the skull cracked or being poisoned. You as the player must send her to the appropriate classes (which will raise related skills) and have an eye on her mood, which may shift according to how she spends her weekends, whom she talks to and what happens around her and concerning her, and which affects at which rate she can learn a skill, where the right mood can more or less double the progression and the wrong mood can completely nullify any efforts in a skill's progression as long as it persists.

While the main selling point seems to be said skill tree and the ever existing threat of being murdered, I did not find it particularly appealing. I cannot deny that it kept me going until my first hard earnt coronation, but my main problem with this system is that it is basically the traditional decision making of visual novels in disguise, which I suppose is there to add artificial difficulty, but it does not. It just lengthens the game rather unnecessarily.
Since it's impossible for you to know what skills may or may not be necessary to avoid being brutally murdered, it comes down to trial and error most of the time. Even then, if you know why you died because a specific skill wasn't high enough, going back to a previous save and trying to raise that skill in time won't necessarily help because you either cannot get it high enough in time or you simply succeed in the situation only to find yourself in a new one where you die because another skill wasn't high enough and the whole process starts again.

I'd like to illustrate this with two examples that struck me as particularly annoying and uncalled for (very minor spoilers inbound). If you just want to continue the review, skip those.

####################################
At one point in the game, you will most likely face a war on sea. You can decide whether or not to lead your fleet personally or let them fight on their own. My Elodie being a strategic mastermind with all Military skills maxed out would lead the charge, of course. So I made preparations and the next week we sailed off. I was ready for a hard battle, with the enemy outnumbering us (a predicament that could have been avoided if I had invested in Divination way earlier in the game, granted, but how would I have known that).
Apparently I could have also studied magic and become a Lumen (a speallweaver in this game), to support the fleet with magical artillery fire (which would be unsufficient with just Elodie, I learnt much later).
Fear not, Elodie has studied great battles and is a master tactician, surely we can somehow turn the tide. Ooops, I didn't invest in climbing, so she failed to get up the mast to give orders using her binoculars. Our fleet was almost completey wiped out, we had to retreat (because her tactical foresight was well enough, otherwise Elodie would have died on the seas unless her swimming was good enough). What? Noone could help her up? Because a princess isn't a master tree climber our fleet failed to get the right orders? And how could I have possibly known that?

The other event is a more or less final battle in the game, in case your hold got invaded. You are being challenged to a duel by an enemy Lumen. If you accept and you aren't a Lumen, someone else will sacrifice themselves for you. If you are but your magic is not high enough, you die.
So I thought, I'll restart the game and become the best Lumen there is, surely I'll be able to hold them off this way. I did, I maxed out all related Lumen and Faith skills and all the other ones required to survive long enough. I started the duel and the game told me our powers were equal, so Elodie would need to come up with a trick to defeat him. I was given the choice to either conjure a magic sword and attack him or try to dazzle him to prepare for a finishing blow.
Since I hadn't trained in swords, being a Lumen and all, and figuring I'd most likely have to pass a skill check, I decided to try to dazzle him. Being a masterful Lumen, Elodie had studied the effects of light and reflection, it seemed rather promising. But alas, the dazzling failed, because Elodie's Decoration skill wasn't high enough. Wait, what?
The weeks of studying of the magic arts and mysteries, the attunement of mind and body, all in vain because I didn't also instruct her to learn about flower arrangements. She died.
####################################

While I like the idea of combining rather curious skills to effect, the fact that you can't possibly know what skills you need and even then how high you need them totally nullifies the point of it all for me and reduces it to simple and tedious trial and error and going back to previous points to try the same thing again.
Related to that is that skills cannot be progressed higher than 50 unless you invest at least 25 in each skill of the corresponding category. But I found 50 to be utterly worthless because every important skillcheck failed and of course I don't know by how much. So in order to really use a skill, you will have to invest in the whole skill category, which is at least another 50 points (which translates to 1-5 ingame weeks on a game length of 40 weeks), which then leaves you open to die for other reasons.
It would be okay if you could finish the game (as in live to your coronation) with any given skillset, but at least in the games I played there are certain key points where Elodie will die if you didn't pick one of the selected skills that can save her.

The story in itself isn't very complex or particularly compelling. With there being so many characters of rather tangential importance and Elodie merely being a mold to be shaped into whatever you choose to, there isn't really any character with huge depth you could relate to and the game ends after 40 weeks at maximum, which is rather short once you skip the known dialogue.

So why do I recommend this game?
Because after I finished it regularly, which took me about 5-6 hours (in which I had fun, don't get me wrong), I looked up cheat codes to use in the ingame console. I raised all of Elodie's skills to 100, so I would automatically pass every skillcheck and the game's outcome became purely dependent on my choices. It played like a classical visual novel and I enjoyed it immensely. Exploring the different paths lead to some very hilarious and intriguing moments (such as being challenged to a duel by an arrogant noble only to incinerate him on the spot with Elodie giving a cheeky grin and saying 'I decline.')
and there's still much to be found out. Things I couldn't have possibly been bothered to find out by dabbling with the skills. Plus, being the rather potent soon-to-be queen felt refreshing from all the helplessly being murdered.

Whether or not the game's price tag is justified I find hard to say. While I did have a lot of fun I can also see it getting tedious real quick. The story isn't that great and if you don't like getting Elodie killed which seems to be point of the game, you'll have a hard time. Plus, there is a lot of great visual novels out there that are completely free.
I think this game is for people who are into VNs and enjoy taking the game apart, making notes on a notepad and figuring out the paths and what is needed through many iterations until they reach perfection.If you just like VNs, you may still use cheats.

reviewText:
Long Live The Queen (LLTQ) is a game I stumbled upon by complete accident. Let me tell you, that was one of the happiest accidents of my life.

LLTQ is an anime-esque visual novel-esque...thing developed by UK based Hanako Games, and it's quite something. LLTQ is a game where you die. And die. And die again. And then you die some more. Yet, dying is part of the fun. For example: someone wrote a silly letter to you about you doing *something* with a squid. Oh, no! A gust of wind picked it up and it's now hanging just off the balcony. Do you climb out to try to grab it?

>Yes
No

You do? Well then, while climbing, you slip, fall, and break your neck on the ground. Your room is on the top floor of the castle, after all. Why would you try to climb from so high up? Idiot.

Except maybe if you picked yes and you actually trained beforehand to be a really good climber, you didn't fall and survived. See, that's what this game is about. Each week, you pick skills to take classes in. And, every so often, you're tested in certain skills depending on what situation arises in your kingdom which could mean life or death for you. And it's oh-so-fun. True, it's very trial-and-error, but with a game like this, with muliptle paths to victory (and many more to gruesome and painful death), that's just part of the experience.

This game is recommended for anyone who wants to become a pretty pink magical girl. ...I mean Lumen. (Same thing.) (Hey, it's a thing to do.)

reviewText:

And lots of replayability. Yeah, it's pretty good.

reviewText:
Princess Maker Lite.  At least, that's what I wanted Long Live The Queen to be.  It actually plays more like a visual novel with a character building game attached to it.  A friend of mine called it pattern recognition, but that isn't exactly accurate, either.  There's trial and error, certainly, but it isn't strictly linear, and there's usually more than one way around any given major event.  The game also contains plenty of secret side content you can only see if you trend and manage your skills carefully, so it isn't a matter of simply save scumming your way to all the unlocks like your average visual novel.  (Though I certainly suggest keeping saves up to a few weeks back for strictly non-exploratory playthroughs.  Playing without a save to fall back on can also be an entertaining experience.)

One of the major features of Long Live The Queen is all the varied ways you can get yourself killed.  In Princess Maker II, for example, you can constantly throw your daughter into the crucible and she'll (usually) be okay.  Death to Elodie, the Queen to be, usually comes swiftly and, at least for your first few playthroughs, often at unexpected times.  One way to avoid them is to avoid the obvious situations where your skills don't fit the situation, but it's never a guarantee the reaper won't show up.  The game is short enough, at 30-odd turns, to make death more entertaining than infuriating, and also adds extra pressure to focus on the skills necessary to get the kind of happy ending you want.

Unfortunately, the shortness is also why I can't suggest the game at full price.  It is a fun distraction with plenty of replayability, but what it offers can't really match the classics I was hoping it could recreate.  The Princess Maker series did have the benefit of corporate backing, however, and this is my sole disappointment.  You have little to lose by picking this title up on sale!

reviewText: Become a magical girl, learn to wield a sword, develop a web of spies and grow to be a cunning military strategist, or, more likely, upset the wrong duke and end up a red smear on the ballroom floor. reviewText:
This is one of my favorite games ever!

One of the things I love most about this visual novel is the fact that the choices ACTUALLY matter... like, a lot. What classes you take matter. What you do over the weekend matters. Who you talk to matters. Your mood matters. What outfit you wear matters. Everything - every little, miniscule thing you do - matters a lot and greatly impacts the story. Elodie faces a lot of difficult decisions and tasks, which makes your choices feel very important. I would sometimes analyze the same dialogue box for several minutes trying to decide which route to go. You may die a lot when you start playing the game... but the challenge is what kept me wanting to play!

Also, when we get right down to it, I just enjoy the story. It is rich with detail and quite exciting. Plus, the protagonist is compelling. Elodie is a character who interests me and makes me want to look deeper into her life. I loved the thrill of being a 14-year-old royal and knowing death could be lurking around any corner, yet having to venture on and try to make the best of every situation.

The options for romance are awesome. I adored how there are the traditional queen marries a worthy gentleman when she takes the throne" paths as well as paths for same-sex partnerships and even no partnerships/marriage at all. Nice!

The only criticism I have really is the classes. I feel like the game gives you ALL THESE CHOICES for what classes to take
date: and only about half of them are ever relevant (at least in the paths I've taken). Why even include them at all? Just to confuse? I don't know.\n\nAnyway
recommended: buy this game! It's the best visual novel ever... I'm convinced that even people who usually hate visual novels could get into this one."
hoursPlayed: November 20, 2014

reviewText:
Long Live The Queen (LLTQ) is a game I stumbled upon by complete accident. Let me tell you, that was one of the happiest accidents of my life.

LLTQ is an anime-esque visual novel-esque...thing developed by UK based Hanako Games, and it's quite something. LLTQ is a game where you die. And die. And die again. And then you die some more. Yet, dying is part of the fun. For example: someone wrote a silly letter to you about you doing *something* with a squid. Oh, no! A gust of wind picked it up and it's now hanging just off the balcony. Do you climb out to try to grab it?

>Yes
No

You do? Well then, while climbing, you slip, fall, and break your neck on the ground. Your room is on the top floor of the castle, after all. Why would you try to climb from so high up? Idiot.

Except maybe if you picked yes and you actually trained beforehand to be a really good climber, you didn't fall and survived. See, that's what this game is about. Each week, you pick skills to take classes in. And, every so often, you're tested in certain skills depending on what situation arises in your kingdom which could mean life or death for you. And it's oh-so-fun. True, it's very trial-and-error, but with a game like this, with muliptle paths to victory (and many more to gruesome and painful death), that's just part of the experience.

This game is recommended for anyone who wants to become a pretty pink magical girl. ...I mean Lumen. (Same thing.) (Hey, it's a thing to do.)

reviewText: A fun and challenging little number.  It's basically a royalty simulator in which you must decide what to study up on between rounds to affect the overall outcome.  You get to make some decisions, but most are made for you depending upon what you know at that moment.  Spend too much time studying one thing, and you may find yourself at the mercy of an unforeseen event that you know nothing about!  While we're on that point, there are many interesting and varied ways to die in the game, and have to start from scratch.  At one point, I found myself going down pathways that were sure to net me a new and novel demise, just to see...\n\nAnyway, it's loads of fun, simple to pick up on, and takes generally 30 minutes to an hour to play, depending upon how quickly you get yourself killed.  Enjoy!

reviewText:
First, this game is hard. Or rather, extremely frustrating. There are basically two fun playthroughs : the first one, for the amount of customization and choices you can make in general, and the last one, for getting that one ending you've worked for.

Everything in between is hell. Prepare to save every single week and do a lot of backtracking. There's a final boss of sorts, which serves as the major obstacle in the game and will require a lot of planning and re-planning.

Other than that, it's a pretty sweet game. The gameplay is unique and the plot is fun to go through.

reviewText: Don't let the sugary pinkness scare you away from this game: there's more virtual death in this game than you can shake a stick at. One wrong move and you might find yourself eating poisoned chocolates, dying by snake bite, assassinated by a family member, or murdered for political motivations. You'll find yourself wondering exactly what you could have done differently to survive. Should you become the shrewd, paranoid hermit princess? Or do you charm the whole world with your social graces?

reviewText: I bought the game during a sale and got a loooot more enjoyment out of it than I initially expected. It's great fun to spend the first while playing the full game through, trying to figure out how to reach coronation without falling prey to unfortunate events (they usually result in your death, but there are other fates that are unsatisfying enough to make you want to try again, too!). Once you've gotten to coronation once or twice, the list of deaths-I mean!-endings is an interesting checklist to complete (I only have one left!), and some of the achievements sound pretty interesting and fun to unlock as well. I'm saving heavily now to be able to tweak my skills without having to restart from scratch, but at this point even if I don't manage to get them all I'm pretty happy with my purchase and looking forward to trying out other games from the developer.\n\nEdited to add: Playing other VNs is helping me better understand why this one is so good. What you choose to study every week has a clear, visible impact on what may happen during the following week(s), because you see what skills are being checked. You can play a very different game depending on what skills you choose to focus on (e.g., I had a go at being nice the first time around and after the humiliating ending it led me to, I ended up putting all my points in military and executing everyone given half a chance in the next run-through ;) Which opened up new storylines I'd had no visibility in until then). You can have spies and send them out to do your bidding. There is no romance as a central plot point and choosing to marry someone (or not) is a more tactical decision. The default" plot also makes it obvious that there are other storylines you might be interested in unlocking (e.g. the birthday party
date: Briony) to explore the game/world/deaths even further. Basically playing other games is making me like this one even more :-)"

reviewText:
I had originally only bought this game to try to prove how easy it would be... and boy was I wrong.
This game is absolutely INFURIATING in the specificity of skill levels.
This game is also probably the most addicting game I've ever bought on Steam.
Infuriating and addictive are probably the two best words I can think of to describe this game.

I was able to actually BEAT the game and make it to my coronation within my first six tries (HUZZAH), but as a naturally competitive person, I am compelled to keep working this game until I reach each and every ridiculous achievment in the game.

How do I get blessed by cats? How do I demand sacrifices? WHERE IS THE TENTACLE DEATH?
Until I find these things out, I cannot feasibly stop playing this game.

I reccomend this to... really anyone who likes storyboard games, or enjoys games driven by plot and not action.

reviewText: Long Live the Queen is a fun, yet frustrating VN/life simulator. Play a young girl, destined to become queen of her country and then make what seem like sound decisions that will cause her to die over and over and over again. reviewText: The game trailer on Steam says it very well!  You guide the princess Elodie on her 40 week journey to coronation by choosing, week by week, what classes she will take and what skills she will build.  In addition, there are a number of events during the week where you get to choose how Elodie will handle them, which often impacts what skills she can build, or at least how effeciently she'll be able to build them.  Some events will always happen no matter what, while many others happen in reaction to the way you handled previous events.  Many of these events are deadly.\n\nWithin that framework, there's a lot of player choice and immense replay value.  It's impossible to build all of the skills in a single play through, and it's very difficult to anticpate which skills will be the most important when you first start out.  It will probably take a few tries to get Elodie all the way to her big day without her being poisoned, stabbed, shot, or blown up.  Even when you do, though, the game still has more to offer.  As the ending screen reminds you, Elodie's story doesn't have to end this way, there are many other options to explore.  And with each playthrough taking only a few hours, why wouldn't you at least try, just to see what happens?

reviewText:
So, it's your birthday in 40 weeks....
All you need to do is stay alive...
But why does it have to be so hard.

Like an old choose your own adventure Long Live the Queen is procedurally generated based on your choices and stats at the time of those rolls and checks. You get to advance two stats per week and it's a delicate balancing act depending on what you plan to do this time round. One thing you can't do though, is generalise. After so many playthroughs you realise you need to have a plan. If you don't want to fight you can manage through diplomacy, you can kick the attackers asses before they hurt you or even turn full magical girl, but specialisation is good. Like you might find in a Visual Novel there is a romance aspect to your developing plot. You can choose a king (or a queen if you're into that kinda thing) that will marry you after your coronation. But Unlike most visual novels, it's very much a footnote at the end.

Honestly I found that it was a lot more rewarding trying to find all the ways to die. XD
Stabbed, burned, strangled, shot. There are a dozen or so different ways you can ultimately end at either the hands of your Enemies, your people or the nobles who lurk at your back. Either way, it's a complex maze of decisions that will give you hours of gameplay if you're determined to survive.

XD

reviewText: The following two things made Long Live The Queen well worth the price for me:\n\n1) It was so creative in its applications of the skills you can choose to develop within the game. It's never quite clear how your choices are going to affect your survival chances--until it's too late, leaving you scrambling for a save file where you didn't make that seemingly innocuous fatal error! Really keeps you on your toes, but it also takes a certain weight off decision making, because you really can't plan that far in advance, so you don't have to worry about making too wrong" a choice. That isn't to say you can't be strategic. The game is balanced in that as long as you cover several bases
date: you can come back from almost anything (provided you have a close enough save point :P).\n\n2) The impressive depth of the story (various important characters don't even show up in certain playthroughs) also allows for massive replayability
recommended: with different routes feeling like very different experiences. This has the additional perk of making the chasing down of the many simple but sometimes elusive achievements not like a chore and more like a treasure hunt.\n\nBasically
hoursPlayed: Long Live The Queen is a really well executed choose-your-own-adventure game that I keep playing over and over again
voteText: trying to get that 100% completion
helpfulPercent: all the while having a great time and being majorly impressed at how it doesn't seem to be quite the same game every time I go through it."

reviewText: It's understandable to be leery of a game with what looks like a generic pink-haired anime princess on the cover. (Elodie is a QUEEN, thank you!) But the game is surprisingly deep and fun, although a bit on the short side. Fortunately, there's quite a bit of replay value, especially with the myriad ways your queen-to-be can die a horrible, horrible death--oh, and how the story changes depending on your skillset and path choices.\n\nThere's a lot of time spent looking at stats and figuring out what bonuses help you build which skills, but if you're lazy like me you can just copy-and-paste notes into a Word file. If you've ever dreamed of being the most adored queen ever, with perfect poise, incredible fashion sense, and unparalleled dancing skills, this is the game for you. Oh, and you can be good at fighting and magic and political intrigue and whatever, if that's your thing instead.

reviewText:
Short, Simple, but incredible complex and full of surprises. That's what Long Live the Queen is. In amount of endings and plot twist, can easily rival Steins;Gate, but in lenght it pales in comparsion.
And when we say massive plot twists, we mean MASSIVE. One single answer or ability check can cripple your ending and send you towards a spiral of madness and death, or maybe not? It's up to you, play, but don't play like you always do.
Want to be a tyrant? So be it.
Want to be a goody two shoes? So be it.
Want to wield nasty ♥♥♥ magic? So be it.
Your choice will become your end.
10/10, needs a ton more of yuri, but it's 'kay.

reviewText:
Our Queen shall live long and be victorious! Long live the Queen!

This is a tale of Princess Elodie, she's 14 years old Crown Princess of Nova and very charming. Sadly, her mother just died and because in the empire of Nova Queens are the ones in charge, she needs to learn about what it is to be a good Queen to her subjects. This game tells a very diffrent princess tale than any princess tales that I have heard, saw or read about. Unlike thoes tales about princess needs to be rescued and needs a husband to the happy ending, this game tells the tale of what I have always waited from a princess story. Things about how to rule and run you'r kindom and learining the valuable stuffs that princess needs to learn. Well sure we had Mulan and Pocahontas, but they are rellay not real princessess. But Elodie is, and she is going to be A (the place where the F word is) QUEEN!

Good stuff
The game is challengin and fun. Cute too in it's own way and has LOTS of potential. YOU can chose what you want to do. Start a war or learn magic and kick the assassin's ♥♥♥. And the costumes are pretty too. It is very likely that you're going to re-paly this multiple times for the sake of costumes.

Bad stuff
It's hard. Everything you do has a side effect on something. You chose the wrong thing and you die. You have not learned the rigth skill for the lvl that it is reqruied in the test, you fail it and probably die. Moods are difficult to handle unless you look the wikia page some help to the moods and mood's skill bonuses. Even I have done it, but I don't regret it. And something about re-playing this game, well, you are going to probably re-play it too because you have died.

If I would say, play this game. Even it IS hard and you can DIE in 10 diffrent ways at any time, it's worth of it. Even the price is good. It's fun, it's cute, it's charming, it's fantastic and I can go on and on and on but, I woun't. I can imaginate PewDiePie playing this game sooner or later. ;D LONG LIVE THE QUEEN!

reviewText:
If at first you don't succeed, you die.

Probably one of my top games of the year. While the game itself is fairly straightforward and simple to play (menu-based), the challenge comes from knowing when to train for combat and when to run your mouth.  The idea is to basically survive. The way that is done is through the raising of various skills in order to overcome the trials ahead. If you pick the right skills to train, you'll go pretty far until you realize that your intrigue skill isn't going to help you safely remove that arrow from your chest.

Verdict: 9/10

To do so you need to raise certain stats and make decisions which alter the story, often in unexpected ways, all while managing the princess' mood in order to aid her education. reviewText:
(In short: It's a decent read if you have the will to put up with trial and error. The story deserves no praise, yet it motivated enough to keep trying to 'save my people'.)


This game caught me off guard. The mechanics of the game put you both in charge of what to study, somewhat like a teacher, and what to do. The results of your actions are not simply based upon which flags (past choices) you have gotten, but also 'points' in various skills, gained by studying, which determine whether or not certain choices are available, and which ones succeed or fail. The point system common in most western games (implemented very well in Cinders), but this is the first time I've seen it applied like this.

It works well once you get used to it, but at times it lead to disconnects between me and the character. Part of the game becomes you trying to teach Elodie (the queen to be) what she needs to get past some event. Fortunately, there are many ways to overcome these events, like learning bad omens from divination ...or sheer knowledge. It lets the game branch out a bit more organically than specific routes, but at the cost of being able to replay it easily.

I wouldn't say the artwork is bad, I mean it gets the job done... but it does nothing for me. It's cute and inoffensive at best, and bland yet inoffensive at worst. You can gain various outfits for Elodie to wear throughout the game, and they all grant bonuses to a group of stats when you use them. The 'magical girl' outfit irks me as unfitting. The concept of magic in the artwork is easily the weakest part of the aesthetics.

Writing is..decent. The story itself is decent but sometimes I question whether I'm playing as an idiot. Elodie has her own personality which is greatly shown in scenes where you don't have a choice. Apparently she's a young go-getter girl with a strong will, but I have trouble understanding how this young 14 year old *sheltered-all-her-life princess*  could say, after witnessing a killing in front eyes, Clean this up." (With an angry puffed out manga-style expression
date: at that!) While on another scene she'd think to herself  "I don't know how to deal with handsome older men paying me compliments!". I think my main complaint about the writing is that age-wise it's inconsistent.\n\nI finished this within 4.4 hours
hoursPlayed: I've gotten to a 'good if bittersweet' end after 10 or so bad ends. The replay value
voteText: I'm not too sure. That depends on how many possible routes I missed
helpfulPercent: which I didn't check too thorougly as I was too focused getting through my current route correctly. I will go back to it sometime.\n\nDespite all its faults and shortcomings
votesHelpful: I enjoyed and recommend Long Live The Queen. Not without caution
votesTotal: though. If you are interested
votesFunny:
I suggest you to try the demo as this may be too 'mechanically unique' for your liking.


"

reviewText:
The idea behind this game is rather simple.  You're the princess of a country and you have to prepare for your coronation so you can become the queen.  The problem is that some people don't want you as queen.  Some people would rather be the ruler themselves.  Some people might not have a problem with ending your life so that this could happen.

So what do you do?  Well, basically you go to school every day and learn stuff in hopes of raising skills to a point where you can fend off these attacks.  The problem is, you can't expect to learn everything easily.  Your mood affects which skills you can learn and how fast you can learn them.

So how do you fix that?  Well, you have a choice of activities that can affect your mood in several ways.  Some activities open up for a very short time, some open up as the result of other skills being learned.  Other activities have desired and less desired effects (you have to take the good with the bad).

If you used to like those Choose your own adventure" books
date: this has a similar feel to it
recommended: except the plot can go a bunch of different ways depending on how you worked on your skills.  You won't just be able to say "oh
hoursPlayed: I need to choose this so I can get the good ending" because you have to manage your mood AND study the right courses to get to a point where that option is even available.\n\nA nice bonus for studying extensively in a certain set of courses is that you unlock a costume that boosts your skills...so now you have the added benefit of choosing an outfit to help you through a tough portion of the game.  For example
voteText: if you know that military skills are needed for an upcoming section
helpfulPercent: you can change into your military outfit and you'll stand a chance of doing better than you would otherwise.\n\nThere's no stress or time limits to how you choose to play the game
votesHelpful: and you are free to plot out how to get the best possible endings...in fact the game lets you save pretty much the entire game to a text file so you can study the choices you made and figure out what went wrong.   If you're the careful planning and analytical type
votesTotal: you'll probably enjoy this.\n\nIf you are the type to spin the wheel and/or flip a coin when presented with a choice
votesFunny: you won't last long
commentsCount: or if you do
column16: you'll have no idea what it is you did to get there.  This game isn't easy...but it isn't frustrating really.  The game gives you the option of seeing which skills failed and which ones passed as the story goes along
column17: so if you die you can see what it was you needed to prevent it from happening.\n\nIf you're hardcore

reviewText:
Long Live the Queen is certainly an interesting game, at least the few times you play it. I was, however, quite disappointed when I found out that most of the  skills our *Queen* can learn are useless throughout the whole game or just necessary for one time and that’s it. This arbitrary system really hurts the game a lot in my opinion. Moreover, the fact that the events of the game are not random but completely fixed, means that you eventually learn how to beat the game just by following a certain order without any logic behind it (besides some hints that end up being not that useful)

Nevertheless, I had fun playing it and trying to get to the end of the game. I do recommend it, despite its flaws.

reviewText:
Long Live The Queen is a game with a fantastic setup and promising mechanics. It sounds fun on paper, and the writing, art, and concepts for how the game works mechanically are all pretty great; in the end, though, I just found it frustrating to play. I'd still recommend getting it on sale if the theme, premise, setting, and art are all up your alley, because you'll definitely enjoy yourself at least somewhat... but I feel like the game could've been so much more if it had leaned more into the role-playing as opposed to the tired visual novel idea of playing the game over and over again, getting tons of Bad Ends, in order to get even one Good End.

On your first playthrough, planning out classes and trying to balance Elodie's mood seem like super interesting mechanics and if you're into the aesthetic of the game and the stuff you saw in, like, the Steam trailer and screenshots, you'll be thinking it's like the greatest game ever. The writing is great, the way taking classes shows you a brief overview of the progressively more advanced topics you're learning in a given subject is neat, and man, like everything about the presentation of the game itself is fantastic.

You notice as you play along that you're failing like every single skill check. You might even be like aw man
date: I missed this Poisons check? Better bone up on Poisons" — only to find that you'll like never need Poisons again for the rest of the game. (Disclaimer: I have yet to complete a successful runthrough of the game

reviewText:
Just so you are warned, this is not a game for kids...  Because why should they have all the fun?

(Seriously, just to be clear, this is really not a game for very young kids.  Older kids should be fine.)

This game is not a graphical powerhouse, and the gameplay is pretty limited compared to some of today's modern games.  It is not an open world to explore for hours upon hours upon hours.  And yet, it will likely reel you in.  How?

What it sets out to do, it does very, very well.  This is a simple strategy game where basically you have to find the secret formula of what to study in what order, and what actions to take to keep your little princess character alive long enough to become the queen.  Sounds simple?  Wrong!  You will find plenty of new and unexpected ways to die!  Some are difficult to avoid.  So, you try again. This is basically the gameplay: try again.  Keep trying until you get it.  For some people, this may be incredibly frustrating.  I found it to be a lot of fun.

Putting aside the cartoon graphics and the magical element, the story sort of reminds me of the story of Elizabeth I and all the dangers she somehow managed to live through to become queen of England, despite the odds being against it.  I recommend giving it a try.

reviewText:
Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/long-live-the-queen-game-review/

Many of you may just look at Long Live the Queen and pass it off as some “girly anime game”. I too thought that the game looked a bit silly, but I was surprised by just how enjoyable it is. It’s almost a masterpiece, which is not something I’d say too easily.

Long Live the Queen is essentially a visual/interactive novel, but it goes a lot more in-depth in terms of interactivity that most visual novels do. You’re tasked with getting the main character, Elodie, to her coronation as Queen of Nova without getting killed. Although the game seems incredibly childish, it’s actually quite morbid. There are several deaths that Elodie can run into, with my first one being an arrow to the side, of which my “battlefield medicine” skill was not high enough for me to survive the incident.

The other half of the game, aside from making good choices, is made up of skills. Elodie can learn a variety of skills. It’s actually a bit overwhelming, the amount of different skills that can be learned. Every week, you have the choice of choosing two classes to take during that specific week, with each skill having its own class. Each of these skills is a part of a group of skills, which is a part of another group of skills. For example, the “Social” skill tree is made up of three skills: Royal Demeanor, Conversation, and Expression. Each of these breaks down even further, into three “sub-skills”. Expression breaks down into: “Decoration”, “Instrument”, and “Voice”. The four major categories for skills are: Social, Intellectual, Physical, and Mystical.

During the development of the game’s story, you’ll encounter various “skill checks” during the dialogue portions of the story. Passing a skill check is always good, as it progresses the story in a positive way (and can help prevent your death). Failing a skill check usually does not matter too much, but in some scenarios, failing a skill check can actually cause your death.

There’s also another major aspect to this game, that being Elodie’s mood. Her mood changes based on what happens during the storyline of the game and the choice you make at the end of the week as to what Elodie will do during the weekend. There are four sets of moods in the game, with two different emotions in each: Afraid — Angry, Depressed — Cheerful, Yielding — Willful, and Lonely — Pressured. Whichever mood is dominant determines the skill bonuses for that specific week (each “turn” in the game is another week). Each mood gives a bonus and a penalty to certain skills. The “depressed” mood gives a bonus to expression and animal handling, but a penalty to royal demeanor, conversation, and athletics, with all other skills remaining neutral. This can be used to greatly improve any of Elodie’s skills, depending on her mood that week.

Long Live the Queen was a very, very fun experience. If I had to criticize the game, I’d note that the player has no idea which moods correspond to which skills in terms of bonuses and penalties (until you have that specific mood), so the use of a wiki is almost essential. I prefer to go at it and learn myself, but I could understand one using a wiki to avoid getting penalties when attending classes. Also, unless you use a wiki, you’ll have no idea when a certain skill will be required anytime during the story. You may get the hang of it after playing the game for an extended period of time though. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
A pretty basic game overall.  I enjoyed it for a little bit, but overall I think it's lacking.  There are two main reasons why I find this game a bit lack-luster, and you can take them for what they are worth:

1.)  Every playthrough has the same plot.  So if you die (which you almost certainly will), you have to sit through the same plot devices every round.  Although there are clearly efforts made to give you several options, I still found myself trying to skip fast enough to get to new plots.  I think randomized events mixed into a few core events would have made replaying much more fun.

2.)  The way that bonuses work make it super beneficial to max out a set of skills.  The more you know about a skill, the more you learn by training that skill.  You should avoid this trap, because if you are missing a few particular skill, it could lead to you dying very early in the game.  I think they could have been more creative about how the went about skill training to encourage a more diverse skillset and allow players to succeed in more skill checks.

Those two reasons are primarily why I couldn't keep playing this game.  It is worth a playthrough or two if you can get it cheap and like sim games, but not something you'll likely want to keep coming back to.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of the type of games and don't get me wrong, I'm not bashing the game or say it isn't entertaining (I'll probably play it again, once the bitterness of dying because I don't own a dog while being the equivalent of an archmage subsides).

The thing is, when I pick up a game like this one I expect to have fun discovering the multiple endings it contains, not trying my hardest not to die and then find out which ending I end up with.
I understand the concept of the game is to live different lives
recommended: but when I actually played it just felt like a game of memorization; the story is kind of generic and there doesn't exist much foreshadowing in it.\nThere should be something in the narrative that tells me certain skills might be necessary in the future
hoursPlayed: but instead it's just a game of trial and error
voteText: which becomes tiring after a number of playthroughs.\n\nMy biggest gripe is that most events happen out of the blue
helpfulPercent: and as the story progresses they need bigger and bigger skill checks. The problem with this is that if you neglected said skill (or group of) you're toast; you were practically dead 10 turns ago
votesHelpful: but you just have to keep playing until the game decides to kill you.\n\nSeeing the tweaks that have been made to the game
votesTotal: I believe that something could be done to help the gameplay without straying from the concept of the game. For example
votesFunny: starting a new game from a previous death while inheriting a part of your previous skills would make sense
commentsCount: while also giving it genuine replay value (other than having a list of "things to study by turn X to not die").\n\nThis is a game for the hard-core and can actually be pretty entertaining if you enjoy that "grinding"
column16: but I wouldn't recommend it for everyone because of said reasons."

reviewText:
I find this game incredibly frustrating. You get killed repeatedly with no warning, and often without being able to properly appraise how you could have avoided it, or even which skills might have let you avoid it. There's really nothing to this game except playing it over and over again until you learn what precise combo of skills lets you become who you want to become, and it overall just feels like an incredible time-sink with very little reward for the player.

Example - I trained to be a badass magical warrior, with high Swordsmanship, Magical attack, and Magical defence. I then lost a magical duel because I'd never studied flower arranging. I could not have known that was coming, except by doing all that, dying, and then starting -completely over- and training my princess very slightly differently.

This is the bulk of Long Live the Queen's gameplay.

reviewText: LLtQ is a good game. Good, but not the best. It suffers from some repetition in that a good portion of the time you invest will be spent attempting to figure out which combinations of choices you make will lead to each ending (and avoid death in the process). The save feature cuts down on this a bit, but if you haven't had previous experience with this type of game, then you are going to be doing a lot of backtracking and starting over. On the other hand, if you know the trick to playing this sort of resource management game, you can easily earn your crown with a half-dozen deaths or less, and in just a couple of hours. The multiple endings add replay value, but you still face the same issues mentioned before. I found the art, UI, and story to be sufficiently engaging, but the music felt somewhat generic, and the $9.99 price tag seems a tad high. I would say buy this when it is on sale for maximum bang for your buck. In the meantime, if you still want to play a game like LLtQ, try the Princess Maker games. They are much more in-depth and have an RPG element to them as well.\n\nOverall, I give this game a 7/10 - good enough to own and play, bad enough to be a little picky as to when you get your copy, and put it off in favour of better games.

reviewText: This game is quite pretty, yes, but it's essentially a shorter watered-down version of one of the Princess Maker games. While it was fun for a few playthroughs, I found myself constantly comparing it to PM. It lacked the many wide and varied options of that game, the only way to raise your character, the Princess Elodie was to bring her up to become a queen, while in PM games, you can name her anything, and raise anything from a ♥♥♥♥♥ to the queen of Hell, or send your girl off on quests. You also only get one year in LLTQ, as opposed to the 8 years of game time in a round of PM. The other obvious difference between the two games is that in LLTQ, Elodie can die. And she will die. On most playthroughs.

reviewText:
I started out as such a hopeful little pre-queen. I learnt the things I should, like how to talk to nobles like you care, how to courtsey gracefully and hide your eyerolling, how to stare down a room full of judgemental arses...

Sadly I didn't think, didn't know. And how could I?

How could I know that I, as a beautiful and elegent young princess, would ever need to know how to climb? Or falconry? ...Or reflexes ...divination ...battlefield medicine?!

Oh come on! What the hell do I pay you people for?!

Does no one check for poison these days? What were those scouts doing? Lounging under a tree? Did the carriage pass them at all on our merry way into that ambush? A peasant uprising??? Why was I not alerted earlier?! That's it. FIred. You're all FIRED! I simply cannot work under these conditions!

So many failed skill checks...

Would definitely die again.

reviewText:
I have played this game for a little over an hour and a half, and thus far I have been:
shot by an arrow (twice),
poisoned, and
stabbed by an angry noble in a duel.

This game is addicting in the way Choose Your Own Adventure books are addicting; when you make the wrong choice, you want to go back and try again. Unfortunately, unlike those books you can't necessarily just go back to the last choice you made and start over; some events are the result of choices you made much eariler in the game. (Hint: frequent saves on multiple save files are your very, very best friend.) This game also benefits from the reasonably engaging story line (drama and intrigue galore; shades of Game of Thrones), stats system based on education (appealing to my dorkiest tendencies), and general adorableness even when your princess is skewered on somebody's rapier. It's a bit like a visual novel and RPG meshed in an oddly endearing way. I'm a little frustrated with my inability to progress beyond a certain point, but that's my fault for not saving more often!

TL;DR: Fun for OCD nihilists everywhere!

reviewText: While it may seem daunting, the game is really very good provided you're into that sort of thing. A largely story-driven affair, I really enjoy my time playing this one. If you've played through visual novels before, a large portion of the game will be familiar to you, with lots of reading alongside static images. The neat part comes from leveling up the skills provided to the princess. Often with games of this sort, I feel that it's largely formulaic. Once you have the parts down pat, the game loses it's interest. Long Live The Queen, however, deviates from this formula by throwing random events in alongside the normal story's progression. While certain events will happen each playthrough, sometimes new things will pop up at inconvinient times because of your skill progression or previous choices; it really keeps you on your toes.\n\nTL;DR: If you like reading and don't get frustrated by retrying often, get this game.

reviewText:
This is a fun, little game where you might lose all sense of time while playing, because you start over and over to get things right the next time. There are a whole loads of options and ways to go, and also lots of ways to die. Be on your guard.

This is my first time with a visual novel rpg, and even though there are little to none animations the game is still pretty dynamic and absolutely has a soul. The images and scenes described in the game plays through my head like a movie while I play, and the game lets me use my imagination instead of showing me every single detail.

Do you like visual novels or rpgs? Take this for a test ride, you'll surely have some fun with it!
